Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Medium: Collaborative Research: Architecture and System Support for Power-Agile Computing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Short battery lifetimes are one of the top complaints of today's smartphone users and are limiting the transformative potential of these mobile devices. Hardware components continue to offer new energy-saving features, but today's mobile operating systems are ill-prepared to utilize these new capabilities. This project investigates novel hardware-software coordination mechanisms to make use of existing and next-generation hardware energy-saving features more effectively. The focus is improving "power agility", a measure of a system's ability to adaptively reallocate energy between hardware components to meet the changing needs of running applications, through the introduction of new operating system interfaces and abstractions.

In contrast to previous approaches that attempt to manage energy directly, this project explores the idea of measuring and managing energy inefficiency, defined as the amount of extra energy actually used to perform a task above the minimum required for the task. Allocating inefficiency, rather than energy, addresses many of the problems with previous energy management approaches while still allowing the operating system to prioritize energy usage between tasks. By allocating inefficiency, power-agile operating systems can safely allow tasks to tune hardware components directly using userspace tuning libraries, allowing them to make cross-component tradeoffs in response to changing requirements while pursuing a wide variety of different energy management strategies. The project also integrates education with the research through a new course on power-agile computing at both of the collaborating institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our work laid the foundation for improved energy and thermal management on smartphones and other modern mobile devices. We explored new algorithms for intelligently allocating energy between multiple device components that can individually make energy and performance tradeoffs. To measure the effectiveness of our approach, we invented and defined a new metric called inefficiency. Inefficiency measures the amount of energy that was consumed that did not improve performance—energy that was wasted and did not make things faster or improve the user experience. Using our measure of inefficiency, we were able to show that our new algorithms both saved energy and improved performance compared with current approaches. We conducted experiments using gem5, a full-system simulator, and on actual Android smartphones.

Inefficiency was used to study the tradeoffs, in terms of energy and performance, in next generation mobile systems where both the processor and memory can be managed separately. In these systems, the voltage and frequency of the processor and the memory can be selected independently, but these settings, depending on the application, are interdependent. We developed a set of algorithms and models to efficiently select the best settings (voltage and frequency) for memory and the processor given the current needs of the application. These algorithms were faster than the current state of the art, CoScale. 

We developed new metrics to evaluate Power-Agile systems. Power-Agile systems should be able to quickly respond to user needs to provide the proper performance and energy efficiency as applications change. The Power-Agile metrics we develop compare the settings selected by the system to the oracle optimal, the best settings if the full knowledge of the application was known. Our metrics isolate two parts of the configuration process, selecting the optimal settings and switching to new settings quickly. The hope is that these metrics can be used to evaluate next generation mobile systems.

We also uncovered and investigated the substantial effect of temperature on the performance of mobile devices. Processors generate heat as they run, but they also get less efficient as they get hotter. In extreme cases, the entire processor must be shut down when the temperature gets too high, to avoid permanent damage to the processor and to the entire device.  Our study of temperature also exposed a previously poorly understood side effect of the device manufacturing process. The process of manufacturing transistors—the basic building block of computer processors—is inexact. Some transistors emerge better than others. When processors that power desktop and servers are sold, the prices incorporate this variation, since it affects how fast the processors can run. In contrast, this variation is hidden when mobile processors are sold. Instead of having the processors run at different speeds, manufacturers constrain all processors to run at the same speed but at different voltages. However, the inherent variation between the processors remains and still has an impact. Our work has developed new tools allowing users to determine the quality of their device; in our future work, we will continue to draw attention to these variations.
